Chicago May 3rd/88
Mr H.B. Stone
Genl. Manager of C.B. and Q. 
JE      City
Dear Sir
Following you will please find copy of my Opt. J.E. reports
Friday Apr 13th/88 
To day in Clinton.
At 6:30 Am Opt. went on duty and relieved the night guards at the same time and nothing happened of importance during his watch.
Saturday Apr 14/88
To day at 6:30 Am. went on duty and relieved the night watch at the same time. Nothing of importance happened during this time. 
Sunday Apr 15/88
Everything was very quiet today and nothing of importance occurred. Opt. went on duty at 6:30 AM and remained on until 6:30 Pm. 
Monday Apr 16th/88
To day at 6:30 Am Opt. went on duty and relieved the night guards at the same time. he also received a report from Opt.




Chicago May 3rd, 1888
Mr H.B. Stone
General Manager of C.B. and Q. 
JE      City
Dear Sir
Following you will please find copy of my Operative J.E. reports
Friday Apr 13th, 1888 
Today in Clinton.
At 6:30 Am Operative went on duty and relieved the night guards at the same time and nothing happened of importance during his watch.
Saturday Apr 14, 1888
Today at 6:30 Am. went on duty and relieved the night watch at the same time. Nothing of importance happened during this time. 
Sunday Apr 15, 1888
Everything was very quiet today and nothing of importance occurred. Operative went on duty at 6:30 a.m. and remained on until 6:30 p.m. 
Monday Apr 16th, 1888
Today at 6:30 a.m.  Operative went on duty and relieved the night guards at the same time. he also received a report from Operative
Completed

2
"E" at Fulton that everything was all right there: everything was quiet in Clinton also Opt says that the B.C.R.&N. Engines are comming[sic] to do the stodching tomorrow instead of the "2" engines that have been doing it right along. 
Wednesday Apr 18th/88
To day at 6:30 Am Opt. posted the day guards and relieved the nights watch at the same time and at 3 Pm Opt. "8" at Fulton reported everything quiet in that place and nothing occured [sic] in Clinton of importance. 
Thursday Apr 19/88
At 6:30 Am to day Opt posted the day guards and relieved the night watch at the same time: nothing of importance happening during the day. 
Yours respectfully
Pinkerton's National Det Agency
By Wm A Pinkerton 
Genl. Supt. of West. Div.
Completed

Chicago. Aug. 1st 1888
H.B. Stone Esq
Genl. Mgr. @ M&O RR
City
Dear Sir:
Following you will please find reports of Officers W.T.T. for. July 27, 28, 29, & 30.
Friday, July 27th/88
Today in Clinton Officer relieved he night guards as of A. M. and every thing was very quiet during the day and night.
Saturday, July 28th/88
Today in Clinton Officer relieved the night guards at 9 AM and they reported every thing quiet during the night, and nothing unusual took place during the day.
Sunday July 29th/88
Today in Clinton Officer relieved the night guards as of AM. The day and night passed off very quiet.
Monday July 30th/88
Today in Clinton Officer relieved the night guards as of A.M and they reported every thing very quiet during
Completed

2/
the night, it was also very quiet during the day.
Yours Respectfully,
Pinkerton's Nat. Det. Agency
By W.A. Pinkerton
Genl Supt. W. Div.
A.R.




2/
the night, it was also very quiet during the day.
Yours Respectfully,
Pinkerton's Nat. Det. Agency
By W.A. Pinkerton
Genl Supt. W. Div.
A.R.

Mar 31 -
I have /also/ seen O'Brien about this matter, & he has promised to give the matter prompt attention & assured me that there would be no further reasion for complaint --
I did not tell him the source of our information but said we were entirely satisfied of its validity -
H.D.W.
Completed

R.I.P.  W. A.D. 
Chicago May 2nd 1888
H. B Stone
Genl Manager of C B and Q City
Dear Sir,
Following please find reports of my operations "R I P"
Thursday April 12th / 88
Today in Creston
At 7 PM Opt. went on duty at the above years and remained on same untill the day watch came on at 7 Am the 13th unclear: he reports everything remained quiet during the night.
Friday, Apr 13th/88
Today at 7 Pm Opt. went on duty at the above yards and remained untill 7 Am the next morning. Opt. says at 8 Pm. a switchmen was attacked on Adams St behind the depot by 4 or 5 strikers and he drew his revolver and fired 2 shots in the air and then made his escape. Nothing else happened during the night.
Saturday. Apr 14/88
At 7 Pm Opt went on duty in the yards and remained on same untill 7 Am. At 4:20 Am Opt hear a whistle in the yard and upon
Completed

investigation it proved to be the passenger train that left the depot at 4:10 AM in colision with a freight train about a mile and a half from Creston going west, one fireman was killed and a brakeman had his left leg broken and some injuries about the head. The wreck was previously described in Opt. "W.A.D" Report of Apr 15/88.
Sunday Apr 15/88
Today at 7 PM Opt went on duty in the yards and was on untill the day guard come on at 7 AM of the 16/88 and he says that everything remand quiet during the night.
Tuesday Apr. 17/88
Today at 7 PM Opt. went on duty and remained on untill 7 AM the next morning and he says everything remained very quiet all night.
Wednesday Apt. 18/88
At 7 PM Opt. went on duty at the yards and stayed on all night without anything of importance happening
Completed

M.F.
Chicago May 3/88
Mr. H. B. Stone
Genl. Manager of CB and unclear
City
Dear Sir
Following you will please find copy of my operative "M. Freport
Thursday Apr 12/88
Today in Creston
Opt. went on duty at 7 PM and remained untill 7 aM the next morning everything remained very quiet during his watch and nothing of importance occurred.
Friday Apt. 13th 1888
Today Opt. went on duty at 7 PM and remained untill 7 AM the next morning. he visited the men several times during the night and found the attending strictly to their duty. At 8 AM a unclear was knocked down on Adams St. north of the RR depot and wihipped by the strikers he used his pistol twice without any effect and they took his pistol from him and did not hurt him very much nothing else occurred of any note during the night and Opt. discontinued.
Completed

Saturday Apr 14/88
Today at Creston Opr went on duty at 7 PM and remained on untill the next morning: he visited the men at their posts several times during the night and found them attending strictly to their duty.
Sunday Apr 15th/88
Opr. went on duty at 7 PM today and remained on untill he was relieved by the night guards at 7 AM the next morning and nothing of importance happened.
Yours Respectfully
Pinkerton National Det. Agency
byWm A Pinkerton
Genl. Supt of Wes. Dive.
Completed

Chicago May 1st/1888

H.B Stone
Genl Manager of the CBD City
Dear Sir
Following please find reports of my operative "W.A.D."
Wednesday April 88'
To-day in Creston
Opt. this morning after having breakfast walked over the companys' property and found everything in good order and very few of the strikers are around the streets.  At 6.45PM the night guards went out and at 8.20PM foreman Frank O Heffern told operative that he had been assaulted by a striker name John Donohue as he was leaving his home to go to work.  Opt. then had Donehue arrested and his trial is set for Friday April 13th.  Opt says there was considerable stone throwing during the night and as Mr Brown was crossing the street he was hit by a stone thrown by some striker, but it could not be found out who did it and Mr Brown was not hurt, stones were also thrown at a
Completed

2

driving car and some of the windows were broke.  At 11.15PM stones were thrown at Mr Stones private car, a window was broken but no one was hurt.  Opt. says this is the first night there was any stone throwing and he has most of the men on the R.R where most of the stone throwing is going on after trying to find the (([person???])) without success at 11.45PM he retired.
Thursday April 12th 1888
This morning at 7.30AM Opt. walked over the companys property and found everything in good order and nothing occurred during the day and at 6.15PM the night force went on duty and everything remained very quiet during the night and at 9PM Opt. discontinued.
Friday April 13th 1888
This morning Opt. went to the vicinity of the depot and remained there all day  until 3.15PM and everything remained very quiet during the day up to this time.  There was a rumour around the yard this afternoon that the new break men and (([unknown})) are going to strike Saturday morning but Opt. does not know how much truth there is in it and some of the new men said if the Pinkerton guards were taken away "as it was talked of" they would not remain any longer in (([Creston???])) but Opt. told them not to pay
Completed

3

any attention to the reports the strikers caused to be spread around.  At 6.45PM the night men went on and a short time after there was a fight between the 4 new men foremen named Halpin, Murphy, Tarry and Bryant who on their way to the Post Office and just across the street they were set upon by a crowd of strikers Halpin and Marko got away from them and was not hurt in any way but a Switchman named Frank Long was struck by a man named Hall a striking Switchman and knocked down in the street and kicked but as soon as he got his hand free he drew his revolver and  fired into the crowd but did not hit anyone; they then took his revolver away from him and in the mean time (Foreman Bryant was running away and seeing that a man was running after him he ran for Millers Hotel on (([unknown St])) and right near the door he was knocked down with a revolver and his  assailant got away.  Mr Miller said he could identify this man.  There was no trouble on the company property during the day and at 12 o clock at night Opt. discontinued.
Saturday April 14th 1888
This morning at 7.30AM Opt. walked over the companys property and found everything in good order and after dinner until 3PM when he went to the depot where the pay master was paying of the new mens
Completed

4

everything passed off without any trouble and at night the new men passed all the strikers up town as they were going to the different stores getting things they needed and returned to their quarters on the companys property and no one complained of being assaulted in any way while on the street.  Opt. says that John Donehue the striker that assaulted Frank (([unknown])) last Wednesday night was fined $10.50 or thirty days in the County Jail.  Opt. says  there are (4) strikers in town that cause all the trouble named John Donehue, Hall, Terry and Black Jack, these men do all their assaulting on the streets as whenever they come down on the companys property they are immediately ordered off & they go.
At 6.45 PM Opt. had the night men out and remained with them until 11.45PM when he discontinued.
Sunday April 15th 1888
This morning at 5AM Opt. was notified by the guards that there was an accident about a mile west of the depot and upon observring there he found that a Freight and a passenger train had collided but none of the passengers were hurt; the Mail Car caught fire and burned up and most of the mail was saved and the engine two freight and one baggage care was destroyed.  The fireman on the Freight train was killed and some of the Brakemen was badly hurt
Completed

5

Opt did not who was to blame for the accident.  He  (([unknown))] around all day and at 6.45 PM posted the night men and nothing of importance occurred up to 11PM at which time he had discontinued.
Tuesday April 17/88
This morning at 8AM Opt. walked over the companys property and found everything in good order and up to 6.30PM nothing unusual occurred at which time the night guards went on duty and up to 9PM nothing occurred at which time Opt. discontinued.
Wednesday April 18/88
This morning Opt. walked over the companys' property at 8AM and found everything in good order and then went to the depot and remained all day and at 6.45PM the night guards went on.  At 10PM Opt. discontinued up to which time nothing of importance occurred.
Yours Respectfully
Pinkerton National Det. Agency
By Wm A Pinkerton
Genl Supt of West? Agency
Completed

JH Chicago May 2nd/88
Mr B Stone

Genl Manager of CBRR 
City
Dear Sir
Following please find reports of my operative "((unknown))"
Friday April 13th 1888
Today in Galesburg
Opt. says nothing of importance happened there all day Opt. says that last night the strikers did considerable shooting outside the companys property for the purpose of scaring the new men;  outside of that nothing of importance happened.
Saturday April 14/88
Opt. says everything is very quiet there today and he went to Mendola last night at 4.10AM and saw Opt. M who is charged with assault and battery; he did not hit Pierce but shoved him off the platform of the depot.  Opt. found the case does not come off before Wednesday.  He then left Mendoila at 11.55AM and arrived at Galesburg at 3.25PM and found everything in good order; nothing else happened.
Completed

Sunday April 15th 1888

Opt. reports no trouble of any kind today.  The strikers feel confident that the Brakeman will go on a strike this week. Opt. says Supt. Rice does not fear any trouble with his brakeman at this point as he thinks there would not be over 25 men who would strike.

                                                                                                                                                                Tuesday April 17/88

Opt. said reporting yesterday all has been quiet; there was a report circulated there today that the guard were going away and about 30 or 40 of the strikers came within a block of the companys grounds when they discovered they had not left they dispersed.  The report was causet by Opt. calling the guards in to swear them in a Deputy Sheriffs as they only had been sworn the first time for 30 days; they being sworn this time for 90 days and the strikers seeing the men called in, supposed it was to be sent away.

                                                                                                                                                                 Wednesday April 18/88

Today Opt. reports everything quiet since he reported yesterday.  He says he saw Rhodes when he was coming from Mendola last Saturday and he said everything was going on well.

                                                                                                                                                                  Thursday April 19/88

Opt. reports everything quiet Opt. went to Buda today and saw Opt."R.W
Completed

who is in charge there.  He said that some boys cut a tram in several places last Saturday night but that his men were unable to catch them.
Opt. then returned to  Gatesburg and discontinued.
Yours Respectfully
Pinkerton National Det Agency 
by Wm H Pinkerton
((unknown)
Completed

EMC
Chicago May 4/88
Mr H.B.Stone
Geul. Manager of [unclear]] City
Dear Sir.
Following you will please find reports of my operative "E.M.C."
Tuesday Apr 11/88
Today in Galesburg.
Opt. went on duty this morning at 7am and found everything in good order. Everything unclear quiet and he was relieved at  & by the night unclear
Wednesday Apr 18/88
This morning at 7am opt went on duty and remained all day without anything of importance occurring during this time. 
Thursday Apr. 19/88
Today Opt. went on duty at 7am and remained until 7pm when he was relieved by the night guards and nothing of importance happening during his time on duty. 
Yours Respectfully
Pinkertons National Det. Agency
by Wm. A Pinkerton
Genl Supt of West Div.
Completed

Chicago may 4th/88
Mr H.B. Stone
Genl. Manager of unclear City
G.H.
Dar Sir
Following you will please find copy of my Operative G.H. reports
Tuesday Apr 17/88
Today in Galesburg
Opt. went on duty today at 7PM and remained on duty untill 7am then next morning during which time nothing of importance occurred. 
Wednesday Apr 18/88
Opt. went on duty today at 7pm and remained untill 7am the next morning and nothing of importance happened during his time on duty. 
Thursday Apr 19/88
Today Opt went on duty at 7pm and nothing of importance happened until he was relieved by Opt C the next day at 7am. 
Yours Respectfully
Pinkertons National Det. Agency
By Wm A Pinkerton
Genl Supt of West Div
Completed

Chicago July 10th/ 1888
H.B. Dione Wsq. 
Geul. Maugr. C.B.&G R.R. 
Chicago
Dear Sir.
Following please find report of Opr G.D.C. dated at Galesburg Ills. Wednesday July 4th 1888. 
At 8:45am Opr went to the Hall with John Hinckson met Wm Kelly and G McGraw who told Opr. that Renick Martin arrived this morning and the boys will get their pay tomorrow afternoon at 2 p.m. They went to Gardls Saloon where Opr treated the drinks, they then went back to the Hall where they met Bill Devid Geo Hallon and Robt Barnhill. Barnill was speaking about his work on the Iante J'e. said the boys work very hard. They spoke about R martin making a successful trip through the west. They said there is enough money in a certain Bank to support all the Strikers for the next 3 months Heardrine and Welch shortly made their appearance, they asked Opr and Hinckson to go to the White Elephant Saloon. They treated the drinks there they then went to Moors Saloon and played 6 games of cards. They left the Saloon at 11:30 am and went to the Hall met Mylee and Morhell there They said there would be no meeting this afternoon. That most all of the boys
Completed

were going to the Park I and Hinckson then went to the unclear House at 2pm Paul Roberts Frank White and K Welch came to the Hotel and asked Hinckson and Opr to go to Highland park. They told Opr that most of the boys were out there and they had plenty to drink. They then took as car and went to the park and met a large crowed of strikers laying in the shade, they had plenty of beer. They went out boat riding also danced at the boat house. Opr says most of the strikers were intoxicated and did not speak about the strike. The met two new C.B.&Q men but did not molest them. At 530pm it began to rain very. hard. Op and Hickson took a car back to town after stupper. They visited Sallons on Peoria Il. and the Square. They met a great no of strikers. Op noticed no strange or new faces. It rained very hard all evening. Op remained up town with Hinckson until 1045pm when they returned the Hotel. Hinckson was very near intoxicated. Opr took him to his room and retired for the night. 
Thursday July 5th 1888
Opr left the Hotel at 930am accompanied by Hinckson Boy and Itraubing went to Gardls Saloon when Opr bought the drinks. They then went to the hall where they met Updike Maylee and Riley Bros. They said that all the men will be paid off this afternoon. They all stood around the entrance of the Hall until 10:30 am when Op and Hinckson Updike and Riley went to Moors Saloon where they played  several games of cards. They spoke about a great speech that Martin made at the New York Engineers meeting and said that he was the coming
Completed

man for the Brotherhood, and ought to have Arthurs place. Opr and Heinckson left Moores Saloon at 1230 P.M. and went to the Hotel at 130 P.M. Opr went to the Hall with Heinckson. Heinckson entered telling Opr he would be down in a few moments. Opr met Thos. Allison Patterson near the Hall entrance. They said they were waiting to see Martin enter the Hall Opr asked them to go to Allens Saloon and take a drink they consented and remained there 10 minutes then they all went back to the Hall. They entered Opr stood in front of the Hall for ½ hour when he went to the White Elephant Saloon where he met F & J Riley and Hardine they treated the drinks and went to the Hall saying they were going to get their $40.00 Opr remained at the Elephant Saloon until 330 p.m. when he went to the Knox College Ball Ground where a game was to be played between the Strikers and Spauldings Chicago ?. Thos & John Riley B Hardine shortly made their appearance they pad plenty of money and were trying to make a few bets. They told Opr that all the boys got paid and that Old Martin made a good speech encouraging the Strikers he told them to stand together and look out for strangers and say nothing outside of the Hall, as he (Martin) knew the Company had a lot of hirelings scattered about the country and that a man could not be too careful. Opr remained at the Ball Grounds until 600 pm when he returned to the Hotel. At 4 p.m. Opr met Geo. ?atters in front of the Hotel who told Opr he was going to Robinsons Circus that night Opr told him that he would also go. they then went to the Hall where they met Flyn a CB&Q Conductor J Swanson a
Completed

Br?akinan. B. Hardine J Sakey and the Riley Bros. we stood in front of the Hall until 830 p.m. when we went to the Circus grounds at the square we met J. Boyd. Opr asked him to go. they went and at 10 p.m. they left the tent and went to the White Elephant Saloon where the Rileys bought drinks. Opr remained on Main St with them until 11.30 pm. when he went to the Cifton and retired for the night. Opr noticed no strangers enter or leave the Hall during the day
Friday July 6th 1888.
Opr left the Clifton at 83.0 with Engineer Stranburg went to the Hall. met Joe Benso Herb Updike Geo Holton and Geo Maylee stood in front of entrance talking about arrests made at Aurora they say they dont know Bowles Broderick and Wilson. Benso said he believed it a put up job to jail all the Leaders in the strike. Benso said he knew there had been detectives here right along and he had cautioned the boys to look out and keep their mouths shut. he said he would not be a bit surprised but what Old Martin will be arrested also Geo Clark. Updike spoke up and said the Company never had any use for Clark and that they were liable to try and fix him. Opr asked them if they ever saw Bowles here They replied that they don't know what kind of a looking man he was Mylee said the Brotherhood ought to stick to the men arrested and see that they got a fair trial, as two of them are Brotherhood men they shortly went to Gardt's Saloon where Opr treated the drinks and then went back to the Hall. They




Br?akinan. B. Hardine J Sakey and the Riley Bros. we stood in front of the Hall until 830 p.m. when we went to the Circus grounds at the square we met J. Boyd Opr asked him to go they went and at 10 p.m. they left the tent and went to the White Elephant Saloon where the Rileys bought drinks. Opr remained on Main St with them until 1130 pm. when he went to the Cifton and retired for the night. Opr noticed no strangers enter or leave the Hall during the day
Friday July 6th 1888.
Opr left the Clifton at 830 with Engineer Shanburg went to the Hall. met Joe Bernso Herb Updike Geo Holton and Geo Maylee stood in front of entrance talking about arrests made at Aurora they say they dont know Bowles Broderick and Wilson. Bernso said he believed it a put up job to jail all the Leaders in the strike. Bernso said he know there had been detectives here right along and he had cautioned the boys to look out and keep their mouths shut. he said he would not be a bit surprised but what Old Martin will be arrested also Geo Clark. Updike spoke up and said the Company never had any use for Clark and that they were liable to try and fix him. Opr asked them if they ever saw Bowles here They replied that they don't know what kind of a looking man he was Mylee said the Brotherhood ought to stick to the men arrested and see that they got a fair trial, as two of them are Brotherhood men they shortly went to G??dls Saloon where Opr treated the drinks and then went back to the Hall. They
Completed

spoke about detectives. Updike said Old Martin told him on his return that he was being dogged by Detectives. Mylee said he would like to get onto one of them here, he said he would make it very hot for the Sons of Bitches. They entered the Hall at 10. am. Opr then went to Moors Saloon where I met Paul Roberts. Jim Boyd and John Hinckson. They spoke about Bowles and claimed that they never saw him here they say that they don't believee in the use of Dynamite and if the men are guilty they ought to get the full penalty. Opr and last 3 persons mentioned played ?4 games of Cards at Moors and then Opr went to the Clifton with John Hinckson met Chas Stanburg there he told Opr that they had received a letter at the Hall this morning requesting the men not to believe the men accused guilty until proven so. Stranburg told Opr that the men believed it a put up job to jail all the leading strikers he said the letter was from Chairman Hage. at 1.30 pm Opr and Boyd went to the County jail where they saw Ed Roberts and Alex Johnson, Opr gave them some cigars which I had bought, Opr told them about the men being arrested at Aurora they told Opr they heard about it this morning, Paul Roberts having called at the jail Opr asked them if they ever saw Bowles or Broderick here they told Opr that his time will be up next Wednesday. The Brotherhood is going to pay the $200.00 fine Opr and Boyd remained at the jail until 3.00pm when they went to the White Elephant Saloon where we met John Riley. B Hardine John Hertz.
Completed

B. Halcomb. (unclear) told Obr that WmKelly, O'Leary Welsh & J.M Graw
left town last night for (unclear) to look
for work.  Obr bought drinks for the party. and Obr
says Riley and (unclear) did the same.  they then went
to the Hall.  There was a crowd standing about the
entrance talking about the arrest of Bowles Brodeniek
and Wilson.  they all claimed that the 3 arrested are strangers to them.  Opr stood around the vicinity
of the Hall until 5pm when he went to the
Hotel with Boyd at 7pm.  Obr went to 221 Main ST
with Shankiq and played pool and they went to
the hall stood around the entrance until 8.30 pm
when they went to the (unclear) left the show
grounds at 10.10 went to (unclear) Saloon where they 
met P Derio an engineer he told Staulberg that 
he had heard Martin and Hill were arrested he said
he believe they were rumours as he knew Chief
HIll was visiting his Sister on a farm near Henderson 
and that Martin did not show up at the
meeting this Evening he said he did not see him
there.  Obr tonight drinks and then they went
to the Clifton House where Devio left them
saying he was going home Obr sat around the 
Hotel Office with Stansberg until 11.30pm when he 
retired for the night.
Saturday July 7th 1888.
Obr went to the
White Elephant Saloon, at 8.15am.  Obr met
Paul Roberts there and he asked Obr if there were any
strangers stopping at the Hotel Ob told him that he
noticed 3 men stopping there.  he told Obr that the
Completed

Boys were going to watch all strangers and were
looking for detectives and if they dropped to them
they were going to make it hot for them, he said
he had heard that there were a couple in town Martin
has one of the strikers following them around to see
if anybody is shadowing him.  Obr treated the
Drinks and they then went to the Hall where they
met Hardine Riley BRos Heetz. Marrison and Lakey.  they
spoke about the Dynamatite case Ob heard Hardine
say that none of the Boys know either of the accused
they also spoke about Dynamite being used at Creston
la last Thursday night they spoke as though they
would like to see the O.B.J.G road blown out of existence.
they said there would be lots of trouble before
this strike is settled.  Ob saw Martin enter the Hall.
The Boys then entered Obr thern went to the Union
Hotel where he met J Paterson and Pat Riley.  Obr
treated them.  they looked over the register and told
Obr they were looking for a certain party who has been
hanging about town lately they think he is a detective
and described a man to Obr.  Obr said he had not
seen such a man.  They then went to Moores Saloon
and met Paul Roberts, who pointed out a man 
to us, who was drinking at the bar.  Paul asked us
if we ever saw the man before.  They told him they never
did.  The stranger shortly left, Obr and Roberts shadowed
him to the Union Hotel where Roberts made some inquiries
and learned that the stranger was a Commercial man.
They then went to the Clifton House
where Roberts made some enquiries of the Clerk
about strangers stopping at the Hotel.  The Clerk
told him to go to hell and mind his own business.
Completed

Roberts shortly after left and went up town. After dinner Opr, Hinckson and Stranburg visited saloons on Prairie St and the Public Square up to 3.30 p.m when they went to the Hall. They entered, Stranburg told Opr he would meet him at the Clifton House at 4.30pm. Stranburg made his appearance and told Opr that the old men were broke up over they Dynamite business they did not believe in that kind of business he told Opr also that there was a fight in the Hall that some threateneed to leave the Brotherhood and never join again. it was on account of the Dynamite case Opr and Stranburg took a walk to the Gardls? Saloon where they met Updike and Joe Benso. each of the two last mentioned took drinks and spoke as though they expected to see some of the boys arrested here. as they were sure some of the leading strikers have been watched lately, they (the Company) will drum up some charge. Opr and Stranburg went to the Clifton House at 5.45pm where we met Engineer Wardrope who had just come in from Buda. They were talking on the corner when Renick Martin came up and called Wardrope to one side. Opr saw Wardrope hand him a letter, and they then went towards the hall. Wardrope returned 15 mintues later. he told Opr he would receive his 40.00 next Monday. he said the letter he gave Martin was a statement of how things appeared at Buda written by a Sympathizer located at Buda at 7.30pm. Op took a good walk up town with Wardrope and Boyd and visited Gardls, Allens and Moores Saloons met several strikers at Moores, who said they were going to the Circus. All consented to go
Completed

at 8.20 p.m they went to the grounds. Opr also went. left the Circus at 9.30 pm with Wardrope and Boyd visited Gardls Saloon where they remained until 10.30 closing time. Opr then returned to the Hotel for the night.
Pinkertons Nat. Det. Agcy.
per Wm A. Pinkerton
Genl Supt. Western Division
Completed

Chicago July 25, 1888.
HB Stone Esq.

    Genl. Manager C B & D. RR.
    Chicago

Dear Sir.
Following find report of Opr. G.U.L. dated at Galesburg Ills. July 9th 1888.
Opr reports that he went to the hall at 830 A.M. with Engineer Wm Wondrope and met Magnier G. Clank E Mylee and Mitchell standing in the Entrance. They spoke about the Dynamite Case. Opr heard Clank say he did not know Bowles Wilson or Broderick that he did not know what they look like. and he also said "the men arrested" ought to be severely punished if proven guilty. but he believes it to be a scheme of Mr Stones to break the ranks and end the strike, Clank said that Master Mechanic Colville speaks as though he knows Bowles. was here. Clank said the man. Bowles may have worked for. Colville and the C.B. & D. sometime in the past. and may be waiting for them now he said he believes Bowles to be a Pinkerton Man. from what he has heard and read in the papers. Then They entered the hall and Opr went to Moors Saloon where he met Paul Roberts and Thos. Allison and Heardine. Paul asked Opr if he had noticed any strangers at the Clifton Opr told him he had not. he said they were onto parties who are watching Martin and Clanks residences they asked Opr to go to the Public Meeting to-night
Completed

with them Opr told them he would go they played cards until noon. when Opr and Allison walked as far as the Clifton Hotel at 2.00 p.m. Paul Roberts came to the hotel and asked Opr to go to Knoxville with him and see Geo Hill and John Enders. They went to Bates unclear Stable and got a Horse and Buggy. and drove to Knoxville we saw Hill and Enders at their saloon Paul asked them if they noticed any strangers over there lately, they replied that they had noticed few. Paul asked if the parties made any inquiries as to Brotherhood Men, Hill replied that the strangers he referred to were Farmers. Paul told Opr that some of the Brotherhood men used to reside in Knoxville, he just wanted to see if any detectives had been there, he said detectives could lay over in Knoxville and work in Galesburg, it would be risky business to stop in Galesburg as all strangers are watched They returned to Galesburg at 530 P.M. and went to the vicinity of the hall and met the Riley Bros ?Hittman, and all went to Gardls Saloon where Opr treated the drinks, they spoke about the strikers being careful now. Every man will have to keep his mouth shut. Opr left Gardls Saloon at 6.00p.m and resturned to the Hotel at 7.30 p.m. Paul Roberts, Hardine and Allison came to the Hotel and all went to the Republican Headquarters where a crowd was gathering to hear L.W Rogers discuss the strike question a large crowd of Business Men and Strikers had gathered at 8.30 p.m. Renick Martin opened the meeting by introducing Rogers of Creston Iowa to the people. Rogers spoke an hour. His story was all one sided he gave Pinkerton Men a terrible deal. After the meeting Opr met 4 of the Business Men at Buchwalds Saloon. Opr asked them what they thought of the meeting
Completed

one of them a Mr. Sindquist said that the Boys told him the Cause of the strike would be explained he (Sindquist) said he was as much in the dark as Ever. Rogers, Opr says is a good speaker, but explained nothing I shortly met P Roberts we visited saloons on the square until 10:00 p.m. when Op left him and went to the Hotel and retired for the night.
Tuesday July 10th 1888.
Opr further reports that at 9 am. he went to the White Elephant Saloon with Jim Boyd Wm Wardrope and lehas Stranburg unclear J Heinckson Thomas Allison and Geo Mylee. they all sat down to a Table and each one one treated to drinks Mylee spoke about the Dynamite Case and said it makes things look bad for the Brotherhood as there was one Explosion here. They may arrest some of the men here for that job. Mylee said he believes the Company has got the "Hold" on the men arrested and if the men are guilty. Mylee said he wants the men to get the full extent of the Law. Herb Updike shortly after came in and said he did not believe in the dynamite scare, if those men wanted to wreck a train, there are easier ways of doing it than by using Dynamite. Updike said the men arrested will have to be defended by good lawyers and he will put his 60.00 a month to a fund for the attorneys. They remained at the Elephant Saloon until 10:20 A.M. when they walked to the Hall, they Entered. Opr remaining outside. he then went to 221 Main St. where he met Mike Shea Jack Lahey and they played 2 games of pool and also went to the Hall where they met  Peter Erickson, uncle of Al Hedberg. he spoke about the Dynamite Case. he said
Completed

he would spend some of his wealth to defend the men as he believed it to be one of the Company's Schemes he said he doesn't believe in the use of Dynamite, and if those men intended to wreck a train he could have found a more safe and easier way of doing it. Op stood around the vicinity of the Hall until 11.45 when he went to the Clifton House and met Stranburg at dinner he asked Opr to go to highland this afternoon. Opr told him he would probably go. Opr sat around the Hotel wuth Stranburg Wardrope Hinkson and Boyd until 2.00 p.m. when they took a car to Lake George they remained out there until 5.00 p.m. when they returned to the Hotel Clifton at 7.00 p.m Opr went to the Hall with Stranburg. There was a large crowd standing in front talking about Hoge and Murphy's arrest at Chicago. they said the Company ought to take in the whole Brotherhood. They all said they intended to stick to the men arrested. Mitchell said it was a scheme of Stones and the Pinkertons to arrest all leaders, Robt Bamhill who was in the crowd said the Pinkertons are not the only ones working on the case. But that the Chicago city detectives are taking a hand, and that there must be something in it. They shortly after entered the Hall. Opr then saw Martin enter the Hall. Opr went to all the Saloons in the vicinity of the Hall, but met none of the Strikers they were all at the Hall. Opr then went to the Clifton House. At 9.30 p.m Wardrope and Stranburg made their appearance. they reported a big meeting and the men were going to stand by all Brotherhood Men arrested. there was talk of another General Boycotte to take place shortly. Wardrope told Opr that what they want now is all Brotherhood men on all Roads to Strike. Opr sat around the Hotel Office with Stranburg & Wardrope
Completed

until 11 p.m. when Opr discontinued for the day.
Respectfully sudmitted
Pinkertons Natl Det Agcy.
per Wm A Pinkerton 
Genl Supt Western Div.
Completed

Chicago July 21st 1888
N.B Stone Esq
Gen'l Mgr C.B & Q.R.R
City
Dear Sir,
Following you will please find report of Opr G.D.C
Thursday July 19th 1888
Today in Galesburg Opr left the Hotel at 9.00 a.m. accompanied by switchman John Hinkson. They went to Gardt's Saloon and Opr asked Hinkson who were the four men who voted in favor of Hoge's proposition he replied, 'Joe (unclear), C. Phillips, Herb Updike and Joe Ennis. He said all of these except Ennis have been radical members and they surprised the boys. Opr treated the drinks and they then went to the Hall. They met Herb Updike there & Opr asked him if he voted Hoge's way & he replied that he did and that he is sick of the ....... monkeying and wants to see the strike ended. He said the strike is managed by a lot of ....... fools and he is tired of the whole affair, they went into the Hall and Opr went back to the Hotel. At 10.20 a.m. Opr saw ?Geo Clark
Completed

enter the Hotel and look over the old register. Opr saw him take a piece of paper out of his pocket and take a copy from the register & then left the Hotel. Chas Stranburg shortly made his appearance. A reporter for the Republican Register shortly entered & looked over the register and asked young Jim Boyd as to what time Bowles came to the Hotel. he told the reporter 2 o'clock in the afternoon and that Bowles sat around the Hotel all aafternoon eaat supper and then went to bed and was called at 9 p.m. Boyd is a young man 21 years of age. He was a switchman before the strike but since the strike he has been living with a prostitute named Mrs. Pratt, most people believe he is married to Mrs. Pratt. She resides in a frame house in rear of the Union Hotel. J. Boyd is not positive about Bowles, the reporter got him to guessing and made a big story of it which appeared in the evening paper. The clerk John Turner went to a show on the night of May 15th at the Princes Opera House, the Globe Theatre Company made a weeks stand there. Turner left John Hinkson a striking switchman in charge of the Hotel that night and told him to call a man in  room 31 at 9 p.m. and collect monet for supper and lodging. Hinkson told Opr
Completed

he called the man but cannot remember what kind of a looking man he was he said he could not say whether the man was five feet or six feet high. He told Opr that Jim Boyd was not around the Hotel that night he either went to the show or staid with his woman. Turner the clerk can't remember what kind of a looking man J. S. Sanford was. Forrest Cooke, Clark's attorney shortly made his appearance and had a private consultation with James Boyd Jr. Opr & Stranburg shortly took a walk up town & visited Alten & Morley's Saloon. Stranburg told Opr that Clark would prove himself innocent. He also told Opr that he never saw Bowles as he knows of and that if ?Ges ?Mieley knows anything and don't squeal, Clark will be alright. Stranburg told Opr that the Brotherhood as a body believe Clark and Mieley innocent. They consider the case a put up job. Opr & Stranburg returned to the Hotel at 12 noon and got dinner. At 1.30 p.m. Opr met Wm Kelly, John Riley, B. Holcomb & B. Hardine at Flynn's Saloon. Opr treated the drinks and they then went to the Square Park. They talked about a boycott which will soon come off when the Company is freighted from the west. They say the Brotherhood intends to stay out until
Completed

the C.B&Q. make some fair proposition. Opr left them at 3.00 p.m. and went to Gardt's Saloon where he met Chas Stranburg. Stranburg treated the drinks and they went up to Clifton House & shortly saw Capt. John Howard and City Marshall Innes enter the Hotel & cut a leaf out of the register. At 7.00 p.m., Forrest Cooke again made his appearance and had a talk with J. Boyd Jr. Stranburg told Cooke that Capt. Howard cut the leaf out of the register. Cooke shortly went up town. Opr and Stranburg sat around the Hotel until 5.00 p.m when they went to Gardt's Saloon where they met J. Hinkson and L. Turner. Opr treated the drinks and they then went back to the Hotel. At 7.00 p.m. Opr saw Capt. Howard at Brown's Hotel and he gave Opr instructions to call at Supt. Rice's house at 8.30 p.m. Opr then went to the Brotherhood Hall where he met Clark, Miely, Hardine, Hertz, Lakey and several others, and heard Clark say that he would have no trouble in clearing himself of the charges. Opr stood in the vicinity of the Hall until 8.20 p.m. when he went to Supt. Rice's residence where he met Opr. C?W. Opr told Mr. Rice and Opr. C.?W what he had learned. Opr then left and went to the Billiard Hall under Brown's Hotel where he met Al. Updike and N. Fillman & they
Completed

played five games of pool. At 9.30 p.m. Opr went to the Hotel where he met Engineer Chas Stranburg, they talked about the strike and he told Opr that if the CB&Q takes any men back, she will have to take them in a body and pay the same wages as other roads. They sat around the Hotel until 11.30 p.m. when they retired.
Yours Respectfully
Pinkerton Nat'l. Det. Agency
By W.A Pinkerton
Gen'l Supt. W. Div.
AR
Completed

Chicago July 23d 1888
H.B. Stone Esq.
General Manager C.B. & {?] R.R.
Chicago
Dear Sir.
Following please find report of C.W. dated at Galesburg Ills. July 20th 1888
Today is Galesburg Opr went to the CB &O Depot and met Supt Rice. Mr Rice said he was going to Chicago to have a talk with Mr Daws the Attorney. Opr met the ? Marshall of Galesburg who took Opr to his office where he had the pages of the different Hotel Registers. I found that Bowles has registered at Browns Hotel on the 15th day of May under name of J. Sangford. "for dinner" again on the 15th of May he was registered at the Wilton for supper as J. Sangford from ? Va. on May 16 he is registered at the Union Hotel for dinner as J Sangford on the 8th of June there appears 3 names on the Register at the Wilton House. Edward Rogers Elmore Worth and R Smith. Jim Boyd the clerk says that the man Smith is the same man that registered on the 15th as Sangford. Geo Clark got a horse and buggy from Andy Dow a livery man here on the 15th of May at 1pm. and returned with it at 5pm. on the night of the 26th of May. Dow says that an Engineer but he did.
Completed

not know him. but from appearances he thought he was one. called for a horse and buggy at 7pm and returned with it at 10:00pm. that night an explosion occured on the Peoria Branch, on the night of the 16th an (explosion occurred) half way between Galisburg and Watoga, on the 15th of May a man by the name of Chas Hanson met the buggy and horse at Movsers Farm he did not see who was in it but knew it was a horse from the Dow Stable The Top was up and he could not see the occupants of the buggy. M? says that Mr Clark called on him yesterday with a strange man and asked him if that was not the man that came with him on the 15th and went away with him in the buggy and not Bowles, the place where Hanson saw the buggy is about a mile and a half from where Bowls placed the dynamite I called at the following stores to try and find the gun. that Clark is supposed to have taken the caps from. - viz
Murphy Bros.                            310 Main St.
Churchill Wetherby                   220   do.
VanSiew, & Co.                        226   do.
Van Schack and Bellows.         137    do.
Babcock & Co.                          13.   do. none of the last
mentioned firms either sold or repaired a gun of this description. I found a man here by the name of Carl Virginius who keeps a kind of Curiosity Shop. he has a gun of that description but has sold none. He says thinly gun of that kind besides the one he has is one that a man has here he did not know
Completed

his name, but said. "He is a man that sells fish and has used the gun to shoot chickens with. Opr will look him up in the morning.
Respectfully Submitted
Pinkerton's Nat. Det. Agcy.
By W.A. Pinkerton Genl. Supt.
Western Division

Chicago July 23d 1888
? Stone Esq.
Genl Mangr. CB.Pq. RR 
Chicago
Dear Sir 
Following find report of Opr. G. D.C. dated at Galesburg, Ills. Friday July 20th 1888
At 8:30am Opr went to the White Elephant saloon accompanied by Stranburg met Benso ? and Tillman. they spoke about the strike being in prospect of settlement Benso said he was willing to see it settled, upon any basis, that the boys had made a good fight against the ? Road. he said this dynamite case is liable to knock the brotherhood out. Opr and Stranberg then treated the drinks and went to the Hall. Op asked them if they believed Clark and ? had anything to do with the striking switchmen getting left off the payroll. Benso said that only ten switchmen remained here now. that the rest have taken positions on other roads and that the men who had left town were the ones who were stricken off payroll. Geo Clark handles all the money that is paid out. bathed nothing to do with cutting off these men neither did Geo ?. They shortly after entered the Hall. Op then went to the Wilton where Op met John Hickson. they took a walk to Depot &
Completed

got the morning papers. ? told Opr that the men are more solid than ever and that it looks as though the brotherhood would win he said there is a great deal of talk about another boycott if the ? doesn't come to their terms he said the Grievance Committee has that matter in their hands. They sat around the Hotel all morning. at 22 o'clock am Chas Stranburg came to the Hotel he told Opr. that the strike would be settled in a few days said that all the places that ? and Murphy visited except Chicago was in favor of leaving the settling of the strike in the Grievance Committee's hands at 2:00pm. Our and ? went to Highland Park and took a boat ride and remained out there until 5:00pm. when they returned to the Wilton Hotel. when they met James Boyd and Stranburg. Opr asked Boyd if he was positive of seeing Bowles around the Hotel on the afternoon of the 15th of May. he told Our he remembered of seeing a man about 6 ft tall and very stout sitting around the Hotel Office. I asked him if the Defense wanted him or a witness. He replied that he would not go on the witness stand if he could help it and that he had never thought of the chances of his being a witness or he would never have said a word to the reporter or Forrest Cooke. ? attorney, Boyd told Our that Wardrope, who is now in Buda. would probably remember Bowles as he Wardrobe passed a remark that day saying there was something wrong about the man, "meaning Bowles". at 1:30pm Opr and Stranburg Hinkson? treated the drinks. Opr & Stranburg then went to the Square where a Band concert was to be held and visited Flynns and Breckwalds Saloons.
Completed

met Hardines sister and a young lady by the name of Rondine at the Square and walked around with them up to 10:00pm when they went home. Opr and Stranburg then walked up Main St. We visited Andersons Restaurant. Opr bought cigars they then went back to the Hotel. Opr asked Stranburg if he knew what defense Clark and Miely would set up. He replied that Clark told the Brotherhood he could prove where he was May 13th I told Stranburg Op could probably help Clark out if he  Clark wanted Opr to. as he was around the Hotel May 13th last. he told Opr he would talk to Clark. Then at 11:15pm. Opr discontinued and went to bed.
Respectfully Submitted
Pinkertons Nat. Det. Agency

City
Dear Sir:
Following you will please find report of Opr. J.H.
Wednesday July 26, 1888, to-day in Galesburg Opr. reports that it has been very quiet to-day. Some of the strikers are very ugly since Bowles visited the lace yesterday and his finding the dynamite here. Some of the strikers say it is only a put up job to down the Brotherhood yes Clark and Geo Miley who were arrested here yesterday for connection with the dynamite conspiracy were released on bail of $3000.00 each and the examination put off until Tuesday of next week Some of the strikers say that if these men are guilty - they hope they will get the full penalty of the law.

Chicago July 31st 1888
H. B. Stone Esq
Gen'l Mgr. illegible
City
Dear Sir:
Following you will please find report of Lieut. J. H. for July 27th, 28th & 29th
Friday July 27th 1888
Today in Galesburg Lieut. in company with Opr. C.W. spent the day in looking for evidence in the case against Clark and Miley, but learned nothing new.
Saturday July 28th 1888
Today in Galesburg Lieut. went around as usual looking for evidence against Geo Clark and Geo Miley but the citizens will have nothing to say about the case and the moment they are approached on the subject they will turn the conversation to something else. Supt. Rice and Opr. C.W. will be in Chicago to-morrow to see as to which will be the best way to get Miley out of here.
Sunday July 20th 1888
Completed

Today in Galesburg Lieut reports that it has been very quiet here and he has been unable to learn anything new in the case against Clark and Milley. Lieut has been talking to several of the strikers this morning and they say that Clark can prove where he was on the evening of May 26th this is the date that the dynamite was put on the Peoria track. Clark will also attempt to prove that he never saw Bowles in his life.
Yours Respectfully
Pinkerton's Natl. Det. Agency
By W.A. Pinkerton
Genl Supt. W. Div.

Friday, Aug 3rd 1888
Today in Galesburg officer reports that the case against Geo Clark, Geo Miley & J. A Bauersin commenced here yesterday before          Hocumb. There were six witnesses examined for the prosecution yesterday and Bowles was on the star from 1.50pm yesterday until 12.10pm to-day. Chicago Aug. 7th 1888
H.B. Stone Esq
Gen'l. Mgr. C.B. & L.R.R.
City
Dear Sir.
Following you will please find reports of Opr. ? for Aug 1st, 2nd, & 3rd.
Wednesday, Aug 1st 1888
Today in Galesburg at 800am. Opr went to the White Elephant saloon with John Hinkson & Opr. treated the drinks. Bill Devro shortly made his appearance and told Opr. & Hinkson that the switchmen got paid this afternoon between 1 & 2pm. Devro treated and they then went to the Hall where they met Wm Kelly, Geo Milley & Herb Updike. Milley spoke about the dynamite - hearing which comes up tomorrow he said they could do nothing with him as he is not connected in any way with the case and knows nothing about it, & says that he never met Bowles. Chas Stranburg shortly made his appearance & he spoke about another foot race with comes of this afternoon at ? race track, and he asked them to go and they
Completed

consented to go. Opr., Stranburg, Hinkson & Deron went to Mones saloon and played cards until 11.45am when they went to the Clifton House Ed Rogers did not show up for dinner. Opr asked Stranburg if Rogers was out of town and he replied that he did not know where he was. They played cards at the Hotel util 1.30pm. when Hickson went to the Hall to get his $40.00 and returned at 2.15pm. with the money and paid his Hotel Bill. Opr., Hinkson, Stranburg, Boyd and Hagerman went to Yards? saloon where each of them treated the drinks. Hinkson told Opr. that all switchmen get $60.00 hereafter and said the money is flowing in right along and the boys intend to win the strike. At 3.00pm they hired a hack from J. Anderson and went to Seacords? track, where there were a great number of strikers, some of whom were intoxicated. They saw the race and returned to Yardts? saloon where they had several drinks Opr. Hinkson & Boyd then went to the Clifton House. After supper Opr. took a walk uptown with Boyd and Hinkson and they met B. Holcomb & T. Riley at Yardts? saloon and each of them treated to the drinks. Holcomb told Opr. that his father was going to
Completed

hear the dynamite case, Justice Cooke bring sick. They went to the hall where there was a crowd standing about. They spoke of the coming trial, all the men say they never saw Boyles. They also spoke of the meeting which takes place at St. Louis Aug 9th. They say that will probably have something to o in settleing the strike. Opr. remained in the vicinity of the Hall until 9.30pm. when he went to the Clifton House. He sat around the hotel until 10.30pm. talking to Stranburg, Boyd & Hinkson, then he retired. 
Thursday Aug 2nd 1888
Today in Galesburg at 8.30am. Geo Tatters? came to the Hotel and asked Opr. to take a walk, so they went to Anderson's restaurant where Opr. treated to cigars. He told Opr. that all strikers are promised $60.00 a month hereafter as long as they remain out, he also told Opr. that he had asked Supt. Rice for a jo and Mr. Rice said he would see when there was an opening. Tatters? said he would never be able to switch again on account of a leg that has been braking working in the yards, he also said the boys are standing by him. He told Opr. that the men are as firm as ever and intend to remain out until the company comes to their terms. Opr.
Completed

and Tatters? met Geo Clark near the hall and bespoke to them, saying "he was going to take his medicine today, & said he heard that Bowles was here. Clark shortly afterwards entered the hall, Opr. & Tatters? then went to the Clifton House where they met Engineer Wm Wardrope & he told Opr. that he arrived from Buda last night. Opr. asked him if he came to testify and he said he did not, but he came to get his money. Opr. asked him if he remembered of ever seeing Bowles and he replied that E. Clark & Ed. Rogers took dinner at the Clifton Hotel with him (Bowles) one day. Wardrobe said he would never come to town if he bought they would want him to testify. They shortly afterwards met J. Boyd and visited saloons on Prairie St. and then went to the courthouse and heard part of the examination. They left the court at 11.30am and went to Yardt's saloon where each treated to the drinks and then went to the Hotel and had dinner. At 1.30 pm. Opr. and Wardrope went to Yardt's? saloon where Opr. treated and they then went to the Court House where they met B. Devro and several others. Bowles was on the stand. They would when speaking of Bowles call him all kinds of names. The room was full of strikers.
Completed

Wadrope said that the man on the stand was Bowles, he said he saw him at the Hotel. Opr. asked Wardrope if he, Stranburg & Boyd were not going on the stand for Geo Clark & he replied that he was not, he said he would like to help Clark but he could not do so, and he didn't intend to make any false statements. They remained at the court house until 5.00pm when they went to the Clifton House. The men all sympathize with John Bauersen? of Aurora and say he is a much persecuted man. After supper Opr. Wardrope, Hinkson, Turner & Stranburg went to Yardt's? saloon where each treated. Opr. & Wardrope then went to 221 Main St. where Opr. treated to the cigars. They then went to the corner of Prairie & Main Sts. and at 8p Jim Boyd passed in a buggy, he invited Opr. & Wardrope to take a ride so they road around the main its several times. Boyd then took the buggy to the stables, and they went to the Hall where they met Stranburg & H. Updike. There were not many at the Hall, to night being ladies night. They went to Yardts? saloon where they had four rounds of drinks. Updike said the "2" is liable to raise h-- with Clark and Milley, he said he did
Completed

not believe that Bowles was ever a Brotherhood man. Opr. remained at Hardts saloon until 12.20pm when he went to the Clifton House with Boyd and retired for the night.
Friday Aug 3rd 1888
Today in Galesburg at 8.30am Opr. left the Hotel accompanied by J. Boyd, W. Wardrope, W. Harris and Chas Montgomery and went to Yardts saloon where each treated to the drinks and then went to the Hall where they met Chas. Stranburg, Bill Devro & HJ. ? and they spoke about Clark's case. They said Milley would easily get off as there is nothing at all against him. ? told Opr. that Clark is confident of getting clear at the regular trial, he said that Clark has an army of witnesses most of whom are Brotherhood men and he said Clark could prove a good alibi. At 9.30am they took a walk to the courthouse where a large crowd had gathered. Bruss? told Opr. that all the men believed the case a scheme of the 2's to get the public on their side and that the 2 is not going to win this strike for the boys will about know what to do after the St. Louis meeting. He said Arthur is no good and they (2 striking engineers) want another man in his
Completed

place. Busso? told Opr. about the Treasurer having plenty of money here. They remained at the Courthouse until 12 noon when they went Moore's? where Opr. treated to the drinks. Opr. and Wardrope then went to the Clifton House and got dinner. Rogers did not make his appearance during the dinner hour. At 1.00pm Opr., Wardrope & Stranburg went to Browns Billiard Hall where they played three games of pool. Opr asked Stranburg if Clark was going to make a defense before the Justices he replied that he did not know but from what he has heard he believes Clark will rest his case. They then went to the Courthouse where they arrived at 2.00pm Clark, Milley and Bauersien were put under $3000.00 bonds. They left the court house at 6.00pm with a crowd of strikers who claimed that Clark and Milley have an easy case to fight against. They say there is nothing against MIlley at all, but I may go hard with Bauersun of Aurora. They then went to Attens? saloon where Opr. treated & there with Wardrope and Stranburg went to the Clifton House and got supper. After supper Opr. went to the Hall accompanied by Stranburg and Wardrope. There was a crowd standing
Completed

about the hall talking about Clarks case, they all say the case is a scheme of the company's and they don't believe Clark or Milley will never be prosecuted. Milley made his appearance and spoke about this being bound over when the justice should have discharged him. He entered the Hall and Opr. stood around the vicinity until 8.30pm ? Stranburg & Wardrope visited saloons on Prairie St. and the square. They met a great number of strikers who claim they never saw a more tame case than that against Clark, Milley & Bauersien. They returned to the Clifton House at 10.00pm where they met J. Boyd, J. Hinkson, & J. Turner. Opr. sat around the Hotel until 12.30am when he retired with Stranburg.
Yours Respectfully
Pinkerton's Natl. Det. Agency
By W. A. Pinkerton
Gen'l Supv. W. Div.

Chicago Ills, Aug 8th, 1888,
H.B. Stone Esq.
Genl Mangr C.B. & ? RR.
City
Dear Sir.
Following find report of Opr C.W. dated at Galesburg Ills Aug. 2d 1888.
Opr reports that he went to the Court House at 10am and the case proceeded to trial. nothing of any interest occurred, Bowles was on the stand and testified the same as he did in Aurora. Opr spent part of the day going around to the saloons and mixing with the strikers thinking he might be able to overhear some of their conversation. As to the line of defense they were gong to make but could learn nothing in the evening Opr went around with the City Marshall they went to the White Elephant Saloon. Also remained around the saloon of the Brown Hotel mixing with people but was unable to learn anything of importance. The case Opr says will probably close tomorrow Opr thinks from what he can learn that they will not make any defense to speak of but simply get the outlines and strength of our case and will make their defense in the Upper Court after they hear our Evidence.
Yours Respectfully
Pinkertons Nat Det Agcy
per Wm A. Pinkerton Genl Supt
West. Div.
Completed

Chicago, Aug 8th 1888
H.B. Stone Esq
Gen'l Mgr. C.B. & L. R.R.
City
Dear Sir:
Following you will please find reports of Opr. Y.D.C. for Aug 4th & 5th
Saturday Aug 4th 1888
Today in Galesburg at 8.30am Opr. with Geo Tatters at the Hotel and they went to Yardts saloon where Opr. treated They then went to the Hall where they met Rod Newell, Herb Updike, Besro Hauf, and they spoke about the St. Louis meeting which takes place next Thursday. Newell said that the St. Louis meeting will probably lay Arthur on the shelf. Milley and Clark shortly made their appearance but did not speak about this case. Opr. heard Clark say that he would probably go to St. Louis with Remick Martin, he also said that this strike is going to stay on until the Company pays the same wages as other roads. They entered the Hall at 10am and Opr. went to Moore's saloon where he met J. Hinkson, J Boyd and Bill Wardrope
Completed

where they played cards until 12 noon when they went to the Clifton House Opr. asked Boyd if he said anything or mentioned his (Opr's) name to P. Cooke, Clark's attorney. Boyd replied that he told Cooke Opr. would probably remember something about Bowles. Boyd said he told Cooke all he knows about Opr. that he has a straight fellow etc. and Cooke told him Opr. was not hanging about for nothing, and Opr. asked Boyd if he knew what Cooke meant and he replied that from the way Cooke spoke he would judge that Cooke took Opr. for a detective. After dinner Wardrope, Strangburg, Boyd and Opr. went to Stranburg's room and played cards until 5pm. when they went to Yardts saloon and had three rounds of beer. Opr. took special notice that Ed. Rogers did not show up at the Hotel for dinner. They returned to the Hotel from Yardts saloon and at 7pm Opr. went to the Hall with Wardrope and Stranburg where they met B. Holcomb and the Riley Bros. near the Hall entrance and they spoke about the times getting better; hereafter, they get $60.00 a month. The Brotherhood of brakemen are helping the strikers now. They visited the saloons on Prairie St. and Opr tried to
Completed

get away from the crowd at 8:30pm and go to supt. Rice's house and see him but he could not do so. Wardrope asked OPr. to contribute money for a case of beer, so they ordered the case of beer for the Hotel. They remained on Main St. until 9:30pm when they went to the Hotel and drank beer, and had a dance in the dining room of their Hotel. Opr. remained about the Hotel with Wardrope, Stranburg and Boyd until 11.30pm when they retired. 
Sunday, Aug. 5th/88
Today in Galesburg at 9am Tatters came to the Hotel and asked Opr. to go buggy riding with him this afternoon. He told Opr. he was going to take B. Hardine's sister and a girl named Rondine, and that another crowd was out composed of Thos. Riley and B. Holcomb and two girls. They then went to Andy Dow's stable and left an order for a team and buggy and from there went to the Hall where they met Updike, Stranburg, G. Milley and Peterson. Tatters inquired if there was any news and Stranburg replied that there was not. Milley said he could not see how old Squire Holcomb had the nerve to hold him to the Grand Jury. Peterson spoke up and said Holcomb was some relation to Robt. Colville.
Completed

Opr. stood around the vicinity of the Hall until 12 noon when he went to the Hotel with Stranburg. Opr. asked him if the Brotherhood was going to expel Clark and Milley and he said there would be no action taken in the matter, that all the men believe Clark and Milley innocent. He told Opr. that he heard Clark had an array of witnesses & that MIlley does not need any as his word is as good as Bowles in any court of justice. After dinner they went to Wardrope's room and played cards until 3pm. when Geo Tatters made his appearance and Opr. went with him to Dow's stable and got the team and buggy and then got the girls and drove about town and then to Knoxville. Opr. asked Miss Hardin where her brother Burgin? was, she replied that he went to Chicago yesterday to visit some relatives. They returned to Galesburg at 8.30pm and put the team up and went to a restaurant where Tatters ordered the supper and Opr. treated him to cigars and they took the girls home. Opr. then went to the Clifton House where he met Stranburg, Wardrope & Boyd. Wardrpoe told Opr. that he was going home to Buda tomorrow on the 12.45 train. Opr. asked him if Clark had spoken to
Completed

him about being a witness on his case and Wardrope replied that Clark spoke to him about the strike but did not refer to his case, he said he couldn't help Clark anyway as he saw nothing. They sat around the Hotel until 11.45pm when they retired.
Yours Respectfully
Pinkerton's Nat'l Det. Agcy
By W.A. Pinkerton
Gen'l. Supt. W. Div.
AR
Completed

engineer was killed, we also saw two bodies

Ed Rogers, Herb Updike, Lea Best, L Staur
and several others shortly after made

right, that it would never happened if
the old men were back. All the strikers
appeared to be in a happy mood, Rogers
said the County would have to bury the
two tramps, and that the wreck would cost
the Company thousands of dollars, We

remained at the wreck until 9 A.M. when

treated to the drinks we then went

and said the boys would not like to
see anything better than a good wreck once

he said it unclear to show that Engineers\

to make some proposition to the strikers
and have them return but Mr. Perkins

Kellogg Sts. they got to talking about

A switchman now in the employ of the

Watson and Work were throwing slurs at

wasin the wrong, he shortly went to the

whip any striker in twon for money
chalk on marbles. we took a walk to
the ahll + we met H. Updike and several
others there, they spoke about the fuss
they had with the switchman, Updike
said he could whip the scab for money
I and Strauburg shortly after visited
saloons on Prairie St. and the Square,
we met a great many strikers, the

Galesburg, unclear Sept. 20th 1888
At 9 A.M. I went to Lardt's saloon with

machinist who is laying off and on a

Cavanaugh, a brakeman, he told us he had just got in from Aurora, he told Stranburg that the road was doing a fair business. We went to the Clifton House & met Geo Hotten & Ed. Rogers there, they talked politics & Rogers said that all the strikers were going to vote for Gen'l Palmer, he said there were a few exceptions, some would vote the straight labor ticket, they talked nothing but politics all morning. At 2pm. Stranburg went to the hall, I played cards at the hotel with Swanson, Brennen & Boyd all afternoon

Stranburg made his appearance at 5:30pm. he told us they had a lively meeting, there was plenty of speaking done by R. Martin & ? and ? Martin edition of Press and People, they talked mostly of politics they are going to vote, to crush out the private army business (meaning Pinkertons special police Stranburg said a vote was taken, and all but ten were in favor of voting for Palmer, the ten were republicans, he said the boys intend to make themselves felt in the coming election. After supper I took a walk uptown with Brennan & Swanson they told me that the strikers were going to have another dance the 25th of this month for the benefit of the strikers, at the Armory Hall. R. Chicago, Sept. 28th 1888
H.B. Stone Esq.
Gen'l. Mgr. C.B. & L. R.R.
City
Dear Sir:
Opr G.D.C. reports as follows for Sept 25th & 26th.
Galesburg, Tues. Sept 25th 88
At 8:45am. I went to the White Trout saloon with J. Hinkson and Chas Stranburg, and each of us treated, we heard some loud talking on Prairie St. We went out and saw John Riley and a new fireman fighting, at the corner of Main and Prairie Sts. Riley had the man down and was kicking him in the face. Officer Paulson shortly made his appearance and arrested them both Tom Riley (J. Riley's Brother) told me that the new man was a "scab" named Frank Cole, Cole was passing and John Riley asked him if he was "scabbing", Cole called Riley a ---------- and started the fight Cole was badly whipped. They had a hearing before Justice Holcomb and both were fined $6.00 & costs, and lawyer Brown had Riley's case appealed. I met John Riley after the hearing & he
Completed

told me that he simply asked Cole what he was doing, and Cole jumped on him, every body that saw the fight from the start said that Cole struck the first blow. We shortly met E? & he said he would give $5.00 for every "scab" that got whipped the same as Riley whipped Cole, he called the new men all kinds of names, They soon went to the hall & I went to Brown's Hotel Billiard Hall where I met Watson and J. Swanson I bought a ticket of Watson for the striker's dance which takes place tonight. We played four games of pool and I & Swanson then went to the Clifton House, Stranburg came in at 11:30am. He told me there was nothing new, except that the "L" strikers were being endorsed by meetings of Brotherhood men all over the United States, he said the boys all felt good and intend to stand firm. He said the "L" was having smash ups every day and could not put up with the new men much longer. We remained at the Hotel all after-noon playing cards with Swanson, Boyd & Hinkson, at 8pm. I went to Armory C Hall with Stranburg. R. Martin, G. Best, G. Staub and all the leading strikers were there, with
Completed

their families, an Italian band was giving a concert. They started to dance at 9pm. Martin, Best, and Staub and their wives left at 11:30pm. I remained at the dance until 1am when I went to the Hotel and retired.
Galesburg, Wed. Sept. 26th 1888
This morning at 9am I went to the vicinity of the Firemen's Hall on Main St. where I met J. Riley, F. Watson, Thos. Riley and Bill Graham, they were speaking about the new men. Riley said he has $40.00 that says he can whip any new man on the C.B. & L. road, he said Elmer Work would back him at any time. We took a walk to, ? cigar store where we tossed pennies for the cigars. B. Holcomb made his appearance & told us that the Galesburg team was going to play the Little ? today at the ballpark. We took a walk to #221 Main St. at 10:30am and played pin pool until 11:40am when I went to the Clifton Hotel. I met Stranburg at the dinner table, he told me that there was no news to speak of, he said the meetings are about he same every day, there are a great number of letters read encouraging the strikers, he said old R. Martin is insane on the detective subject he said "Martin never makes a speech but what he cautions
Completed

the boys to look out for strangers in public places
Martin talks as though he is positive there
are detectives here, he said a person don't
hear the boys talking on the outside of
things that happen in the Hall, he 
said he would just as soon tell me,
as he knows I am all right, and it
would go no farther, Strauburg went up
town at 1 P.M. At 2 P.M. J. Boyd, John
Turner + I took a car and went to the ball
park and saw the game. We met Strauburg,
M. Hale, Dennis Magner and several others
there. Boyd + I left the Park at 5 P.M.
and went to the Hotel. After supper I went
to the Hall with Strauburg, we met Ed. 
Rogers there. we visited saloons on the
Square and Boone Ave. up to 9.30 P.M.
when I went to the hotel. They did
not talk on strike matters. I sat around
the hotel until 11.30 P.M. when I retired.
Yours Respectfully
Pinkerton's Nat'l Det. Agcy
by N.A. Pinkerton

Chicago Illinois October 10th, 1888
H.B. Stone Esq General Manager C.B.+unclear R.R. City
Dear Sir, Following find report of unclear dated at Galesburg. Thursday Oct 14th, 1888, and Oct. 5th, 1888, unclear reports as follows.
I met Ed Rogers at the Clifton Hotel at 8.30 a.m. we went to the While Elephant saloon and played pool. We met Elmer Work at 10.30 a.m. corner of Prarie and Main Sts. Rogers asked Work if there was nay more news. Work replied nothing new only a Wreck. Two Engines smashed up. Rogers asked me to go and play poker in a room up unclear Flynns Saloon. I told him I did not care about playing- we then went to the Clifton House. at 11.30 a.m. Stamburg came he asked me if I had noticed a man with a full beard sitting around the Clifton lately! I told him I had. he then he then told us that the mans name is Lee and that he was in the employ of the Company as "Spotter" Jim Boyd Jr. saw Lee write 2 letters addressed to Mr. Stone Chicago, Stamburg told us that the Switchman and unclear get paid to morrow. R. Martin went to Chicago for the money- after dinner we went to Room 6. which is Stranburgs room. and played Cards for the Cigars
Completed

and Drinks up to 5.p.m. Rogers said he was going to Catch Mr Butterfield a new man and have some fun to-morrow! he said a striker can easily get Drunk on a new man, and he is going to have some fun. After supper, I went up Town, with Rogers. we met E.Work at the White Elephant Saloon we played several games of Pool. we remained there until Closing time! 10.30 p.m. when we took a walk to 221 Main St. Rogers treated the cigars! I and Rogers then left Work and went to the Hotel, and retired! Friday, October 5th 1888. This morning at 9.a.m. I went to Gardt's saloon with J Heinkson. We met Peter Erickson there, I treated the Drinks he told Hinkson that Martin was going to pay off the men at the Hall at 10.00 a.m, I and Hinkson visited White Elephant, and Moores Saloons he drank Whiskey and got quite intoxicated he went to the Hall at 11 am and got $40.00 in five dollar gold pieces I then took him to the Clifton House, met Strauburg and Rogers there I asked Rogers if there was any new Moves on unclear among the strikers, he replied that there was no news! He said the men are standing fine and dont Growl any more. We took a Walk to Gardts Saloon. Rogers told me that the Engineers and Switchmen got paid he showed me $40.00 in gold coins, we went back to the Clifton and got dinner I tried to get away from Rogers and Strauburg to write my reports. after dinner
unclear could not do so. they wanted me to play cards in Strauburgs rooms up to 4.30 pm with Boyd and [[unclear]. I and Rogers and Strauburg went to Gardts saloon at 4.30 p.m. we met E. Work there they spoke about the Democratic Rally which takes place to-morrow. they claim that things are Coming their way. Rogers said the Company is having poor luck with their men. he said all of
Completed

the boys believed it only a matter of time! when the company will give in. I and Strauburg and Rogers went to the Hotel at 6 p.m. and got supper. I met Thomas Brennan at fireman at Gardt's Saloon. at 4 oclock P.M, he told me that the Firemen had not been paid yet. he said the firemen are going to raise hell if they dont get their pay soon. I asked him how it is that the Firemen are a Month behind he said the fault all lies with Ralph unclear in not visiting Headquarters and Streigheing up books. He said there has been a Mistake made some place and the boys blame unclear!
