Chicago, Jan, 10th 89
H.B. Stone Esq Vic Pres. C.B.+2.R.R. City
Dear Sir, unclear "G.D.C" reports, Monday, Jan, 7th 1889 Today in Galesburg, AT 9 A.M. I went to the white front saloon where I met Peter Treeson, he told me that R. MArtin and R. Lacy arrived in town last night and would be at the hall this morning, He left the saloon at 9.30 A.M. and went to the hall. Later I met Chas. Maul + Thos Riley, we visited Flynn's and Buchwald's saloons + I went to the White Elephant saloon at 10.45 A.M. with Thos. RIley and met Thos. McKinley + John Cain there, they told us that they had just came from the Hall + McKinley said Martin spoke and gave the boys and idea of what the Committee of nine had done, he instructed the men to keep their mouths closed and say nothing about the new men or Q officals McKinely + Cain both say they will stand a poor show on account of talking too much. I remained at the White Elephant saloon
Completed

until 11.45 A.M. when I went to the Clifton Hotel and got my dinner. I met Ed. Rogers there and he told me that from what he had heard at the hall, the strikers had gained nothing and lost every thing and he is also aware of the fact that he will stand a poor show of getting back on the Q on account of his fighting with new men and talking too much, he said he would not be surprised if unclear Rig had the history of all the boys, he said that if he refused a situation on the Q, he is sure he can get work on the Santa Fe. He told me that the boys expect a letter from Cleveland sometime to-morrow giving a full account of the agreement. Martin instructed all of the men to keep quiet and say nothing. I left the hotel at 3 P.M. and went to unclear barber shop where I met Joe unclear and Haw unclear, they said the Committee's doings was an outrage and unclear said a great many of the boys would never get back, he said he has talked very loud since the boys went out and thinks he will stand a poor show of getting back. {?McGaun?] called the new men and Robt unclear vile names and said that if he could not get a job here he could on some other road, He visited Smith + Marblis and D. Morley's saloons and met Swanson + Peter Erickaw at Morley's saloon they said there was no news worth speaking about, We shortly afterwards took a walk to the
Completed

Hall where we met Chas Phillips standing at the entrance, he said there was nothing going on up stairs, I left them soon afterwards and went to Brown's Hotel billiard hall where I met John Riley and J. Lakey, they spoke about the prospects of getting back on the road, Lakey told me that B. Hardine, Thos. Allison, Al. unclear and several other (all switchmen) would arrive in a few days, Lakey said he stands a good show of getting back, We played a few games of pool and I went to the Clifton at 5.30 P.M. At 6 P.M. unclear Wardrope and H. Spaulding of Buda made their appearance at the hotel. They are both engineers. Reuick Martin unclear them to come to Galesburg, they claimed that they knew nothing as to how things are going. I left the Hotel at 7 P.M. accompanied by John Hinkson and Chas. Craig and went to the Square to see the Shaw Battle, where we met several new men, At 7.45 P.M. they went to the Hall, I met John Anderson on Main St. near Prairie St. we went to the Opera House and saw the show, We went to the Clifton Hotel at 10.30 P.M. and I went to Strauburgs room where I men Wardrope, Craig, Rogers and Strauburg playing cards. Rogers told me that he had learned nothing new at the Hall this evening. I played cards with them until 11.30 P.M. when we retired Yours Respectfully Pinkerton's Nat'l Det. Agcy by N.A.Pinkerton Gen'l unclear West unclear R.
Completed

Chicago, Jan, 11th 1889 
H.B. Stone Esq. Vic Pres, C.B.+2.R.R. City.
Dear Sir, unclear G.D.C reports, Tuesday, Jan 8th 1889 Today in Galesburg, I left the hotel at 8.30 A.M. and went to the White Front Saloon in the vicinity of the hall, I saw a large number of strikers going to the Hall + among the number were unclear Martin and G. Clark. Gus Peterson and Peter Truson entered the saloon at 10.30 A.M. they spoke about a letter which ought to be here today. They claimed that they knew nothing at all about the agreement made by the committee, John Cain and B. McFadden and another engineer from unclear shortly after made their appearance. Cain told me that a striker will have to be careful how he speaks about the new men and the "2" officals, He said he heard that unclear had detectives all over the city and any men that talks too loud will never get back on the road. He said it was given unclear
Completed

at the Hall that unclear Rice read a letter to new men at the Round House last night, he did not know what the letter contained. He said all the strikers want is plenty of snow, then most of them will get back. He said it was a well known fact that one third of the men now employed by the Company are not fit to run an engine and that he heard that the Company have twenty eight extra men on the pay roll but said he did not believe it. Cain said a man can't tell who his friends are nowadays, He referred to John unclear case, the way he was taken in by Bowles, he said he would not place confidence in his unclear brother, He had several drinks and I left Cain at the Hall at 12.30 P.M. he saying he would meet me at John Morris saloon after dinner. I then went to the Cliftons Hotel and got my dinner. At 2.30 P.M. I went to John Moore's saloon where I met Cain, H. Tillman + Phil Murphy. we played a few games of cards, They claimed to be in the dark as to what the agreement is, but Martin told them that if contained, more than what was stated in the morning papers in favor of the strikers. I left Moores saloon at 4.30 P.M. and went to the Clifton Hotel. I met C. Strauburg, M. Wardrope, C. Craig and
Completed

J. Hinkson in Strauburgs room playing cards. Wardrope claimed that the so much talked about letter ought to be at the Hall tonight. We played cards until 6 P.M. when we had supper. At 7.15 P.M.  Ed. Rogers, C. Craig, B. McFadden, C. Strauburg, W. Wardrope and J. Hinkson went to the Hall. Thos. Diffenbaugh a C.B.+Q. machinist came to the Hall at 7.30 P.M. he told me that he was very anxious to see Chas. Strauburg and learn the news, if any. He spoke about Robt Coville Master Mechanic calling him up to his office and accusing him of being in sympathy with the strikers, Diffenbaugh told me that he has often give the boys good pointers as to what was going on at the shops, and some of the strikers have in return for his aiding them told Colville. He said he expects to be discharged. He left the Hotel at 8 P.M. saying he was going home, Chas. Craig, W. Wardrope, Chas. Strauburg and John Hinkson came to the Hotel. Wardrope told me that they had heard the letter read, he said they had gained nothing and lost every thing + said that all the boys thought the same. Tey say that they will not report for work , that if the Company want them they know where to find them. We went to Strauburg's room and
Completed

played cards up to 11 P.M. when Edgar Rogers came and told me that the strikers had lost everything, he said the men do not blame the Committee as it was the best thing they could do and says he don't expect to get back on the road, he will wither get a situation on the Santa Fe or go west, he said it is the same with E. Work, T. McKinley and others. He said he is glad the strike is settled as it will give some of the men who have large families an opportunity to get back. We retired at 11.45 P.M. Yours Respectfully Pinkertons Nat'l Det. Agcy. by unclear Pinkerton Gen'l. unclear West unclear R
Completed

Dear Sir Following you will please find report of my operative "J.M." Friday Apr 13th 88
Today in Hannibal unclear report everything quiet there today with some indicat of trouble but he feels perfectly able to handle anything that may occur and says engineer Thomas had the head light of his engine broke by a stone about 2 miles from Hannibal and unclear sent 4 men down the road with him last night unclear in conversation with the nigh switchman was told that the strikers were a treacherous class here and should be watched close. The indications above reffered to are that the strikers assemble on the back of the Missippi in a large crowd and were very threatening in their appearence and they looked very hard at the new Engineer of the {?quincy?] unclear he is well gaurded and very defiant to the strikers

Saturday Apr 14/88
unclear reports all quiet since last report and says the strikers come in show unclear then disapear the same way and the guards are prepared for all such movements as they are very unclear. As engineer Singleton was being escorted from the hotel to the round house last night 3/three suspicious looking men came up close behind him and on being noticed by the guard took a circutious route to head him off and unclear saw 4 men crouching behind the unclear office unclear started there away of the companys property and had them followed where the first (3) and the last 4 men were seen to meet and proceed together. At 1 Pm officer Dusch arrested (2) two prowlers and held them unclear proved they were tramps who were ejected from a passenger train that just passed by. Nothing else of importance occured. Kansas City Apr 4th 88. C.B. and 2.R.R Chcago Ills.
Sir: My Operative W.H.C. reports as follows = Kansas City [[unclear] Apr 2nd 88. "I left the agency at 10 a.m. and proceeded to the Union Depot. upon my arrival I saw a number of men sitting and standing around in groups I mingled with them and after a short time, I entered into conversation with one of them. He informed me he worked for the A.J. and unclear Ry. up to within about three weeks ago and was now ready to take a job of work. He said the switchmen expected to receive orders from the Union to quit work at noon today, but up to the present time no orders have been given, and the men are still at work. He said he knew that some of the switchmen did not want to unclear up their job but said
Completed

they would probably obey any orders from the Union. He gave as his opinion that the Union would not issue orders for a strike. I then left him and joined another group; but after mingling with them awhile found they were also strangers, having arrived in the town only a short time ago. I went around amongst all the men who were standing about and became satisfied that there had been no strike as yet. I went and sat down on a truck where two others were sitting and from their conversation judged that they were some of the striking engineers or firemen, for they were passing remarks about all engineer on the cab of a H unclear St. J. R.R. engine. One said to the other that he was one of Pinkerton's engineers. I tried to get into conversation with them about the present trouble, but they were very unclear and unclear communication and I could not draw them into conversation, although they would talk on other matters, but any question bordering on the present trouble they did not know anything about. After a short time they got up and left. I then got into conversation with a
Completed

man who was a fireman, but was not working at present: had only been in the town about a month, He said that the switch engineers and firemen had received orders to quit if they are compelled to handle "2" freight. He said that the switchmen in the yard had not struck and did not believe they would. I then walked down to the depot and entered into conversation with a conductor on the Kansas City, Fort Scott + Gulf R.R., whose train was about to leave. He said that the switch engineers and firemen had orders to quit if requested to handle "2" freight. He was very unclear against the strikers and said he would kill the first man that interfered with him or his duty and said he expected they would be asking every railroad man in the country to take up their grievances: that they were just crazy enough to ask anything. I remained around there until 6 p.m. and up to that time I was unable to come across any of the switchmen. I then discontinued and retired to the Agency".
Completed

unclear operative C.H.E. reports as follows: Kansas City, April 2/88 "At 6:30 p.m. I went to the Union Depot and circulated among the railroad men for the purpose of learning what might be in contemplation among them, and gathered such facts as might be afloat. I learned that there had not been any action on general [?mooe?] as yet among the switchmen, but a belief that the switch engineers were in a position ready to strike when the question of moving "2" cars should be made. From a general inquiry there is quite a feeling arising among unclear employees whose positions will be jeopardized by the continuance of the strike and grounds for the belief that a general tie up would [?engarden?] ill feeling among the various railroad men. I remained about but a short time, conversing with those from whom I thought it possible I might gain some information. After remaining about the yard and depot until 10 p.m. I returned to the Agency."
Completed

My operative W.H.C. further reports as follows: Kansas City, April 3/88. "I left the Agency at 6.50 a.m. and proceeded to Union Depot yards and mingled with the men about there. I saw that the switchmen were still at work. During the day I made the acquaintance of two unclear + Sr. J. brakemen, who claim to have quit last night. While talking to them we were approached by one of the "2" switchmen: a tall, slim fellow, wearing a cap and flannel shirt. He called these two men to one side and asked them if they were working and they told him no. He them went back to his work. These men seemed to think that the switchmen would strike sooner or later. They appeared to be very knowing and said that they would not quit until they were all ready to got together. The actions of the switchmen lead me to believe that they are preparing to go out, for they occasionally get in groups talking. They also make frequent visits across the street to F. Meyers' saloon. At one time eight of them went over together.
Completed

They yard masters also went over a number of times with two switchmen in white shirt sleeves. They have had their heads together a great deal during the day. I tried to get into conversation with one of them, but he would not take to it. I made the acquaintance of a railroad man from Topeka who told me that he had heard that the switchmen intended to go out. He also told me that the Ste. Fe men had gone back to work again. the company having agreed not to handle "2" freight. I remained around the yard until 6 p.m. Up to that time the switchmen had not gone out. From the general talk I draw the conclusion that the better element are beginning to feel a little anxiety as to the present appearance of matters and begin to fear that the switchmen will commit some depredation and this cause the blame to fall upon unclear and hereby lose the public goodwill. Then, too, the attitude taken by the conductors. The most conservative feel that the crisis is on and the company
Completed

stand is weakening many. These conclusions I draw from the different opinions expressed among the men I meet and talk with. Yours Respectfully Pinkerton's Nat'l Detective Agcy, W.A.Pinkerton, unclear Supt. E.D.
Completed

Kansas City, Mo, April 5/88. Sir: In continuation of above operation My operative W.J.C. reports as follows = Wednesday, April 4th/88. "I left the Agency at 7:30 a.m. and proceeded to the Union Depot yard, where shortly after I met Opr. W.H.C., who pointed out a number of the switchmen who were at work and among whom I was to operate. We then separated and I formed the acquaintance of a man who proved to be a railroad employee and in the course of conversation said that he did not think the switchmen would go out here. They were at work and seem to be satisfied and as I mingled among the men I could find no apparent indication of trouble at present. There is evidently something anticipated by the strikers and where approached on the subject they claim Kansas City will act as does Chicago. In conversation with some of the strikers I talked with them on the loss of time and prospect of the "2" men unclear beating
Completed

the "2" road and noticed while they declare they are going to hang out they don't talk of beating the company, but they hope the company will meet them with some proposition, so they can come back. They don't seem to realize that the company can do without their services. In speaking with an engineer, who I heard called Joe, he did not seem to hesitate in saying he was anxious to go back and wished it was over. The better class of strikers fear this influx of tramps and loafers attracted by the excitement will take advantage of some move made by the striking switchmen and arouse the indignation of the people and draw public sympathy from their Brotherhood." My operative W.H.C. further reports as follows: Wednesday, April 4/88, "I left the Agency at 7:30 a.m. and proceeded to the Union Dept yards and there met Op. W.J.C. I showed him the switchmen at work. We then separated during the morning. I made the acquaintance of a railroad man who appeared to be very indignant against the brotherhood men, although he was
Completed

formerly a brotherhood man himself, but claimed that he had been treated very shabbyly by them. We talked about the anticipated strike of the switchmen and he claimed to know some of them and said that he did not believe that they would go out. He cited instances where the engineers failed to tender the switchmen any assistance or even sympathy in some of their former troubles and that is the way some of the switchmen are beginning to look at the question and again they see how the company are filling places of those who do strike. He also said that if they should be foolish enough to strike he would not hesitate a moment about stepping in and applying for the vacant position and also said he knew a number of others in and about Kansas City who would do the same. He did not think the company would be embarrassed for any great length of time. He also said that the letter published by the President of the Conductors Union was being read very closely by railroad men and that they unclear but acknowledge the truth of it. During the day I also got
Completed

into conversation with the assistant yard master, or such I supposed him to be, for he seems to be in authority when Mr. Heath is away. I said to him: "Well, I see you fellows are still at work"! And he said, "Yes; we're still at work". And he said it in such a way that could lead one to suppose they intended to stay at work. He would not admit to me that they intended to stay at work or quit, but evaded the question. I found him in an excellent humor; in fact, all of the switchmen appeared to be in good spirits and acted as if they had got something off their minds and from general appearances would say that they have given up the idea of striking for the present. I heard Mr. Heath, the yardmaster, instruct one of the switchmen to go down to the round house and order out two other engineers, saying that they had been working with one all the morning and would have to haor more for the afternoon work. I also noticed that they did not make those visits to the saloon across the way as they did yesterday. I also walked down by the round
Completed

house, but was unable to learn anything in regard to the present trouble. I remained in and about the yards until 6 p.m., when I discontinued and returned to the Agency."

  My Operative C.H.E further reports as follows-"
  "At 9 a.am. I called at the H [and] St. J.R.R. office and had a conversation with Mr. E. G. [Lish] asst dupt. and arranged wish him to be at his office at noon for the purpose of obtaining a description and book at one Frank Murphy a striking [engineer] and one who he believed was the guiding spirit among the men. who were intimidating some of the new employ so of the H and On-J.R.R.
  In the meantime I went into some of the Saloons in the immediate vicinity of the Depot and noted that the subject of the strike was the principal there of conversation. from a grasp of R.R. men standing in front of [Chajun] and Gore's Restaurant I gathered from what I overheard that the
Completed

action in Chicago would determine the action here from the tone of the conversation I inferred that considerable anxiety was felt as to what that action might be. not being able to remain longer in the position I withdrew and at noon again proceeded to Mr. Fish's office where soon after I met [met] him and with him took a walk along Union Ave. near the albany Hotel. he spoke to Frank Murry. I was enabled thus to get a good description of Murry. Shortly after we seperated - and I returned to the Agency-

  At H.P.M. I again visited The Vicinity of the Depot for the purpose of giving discriptions of Murry to opr's M.H.C and N.J.C. after some time I found Ofr. M.H.C. and unobserved I gave him the description of Murry and such [niste stins] as were necessary after which I returned to the Agency-
  Yours Respectfully

In continuation of [misdirections] I left the Agency at 7 a.m. and proceeded to the Union Depot Yards I after went to the New Albany Hotel for the purpose of picking up Frank Murry one of the striking engineers who was described to me as 36 years old 5 ft 9 in medium build dark hair and mustache. minus one of the upper front teeth - odd . expressions about eyes wore a black soft felt hat (new) square crown I remained about  the office some and time when not seeing anything of Murry. I went over into the yard and picked up a conversation with one of the engineers (Striker) He told me the Boycott
Completed

had been declared off  and said that he intended to leave the town and hunt up a position on some other [suad]. He seemed to be satisfied the chances were gone here and considered the cause lost. he said the strike was not managed right to win he seemed to be very conservative and did not appear to show any animosty against the so called [scabs]. in speaking of the assault in the [scabs] in Whittakers - last Sunday. he said he did not know the particulars but had heard the [scabs] had been drinking and - and the [Jues] was the [causer] of other causes than those alleged. In speaking of the strike in general he said it was about over and it had jailed from mismanagement. [Arthur] was getting to old.

Completed

any - but he would like to see the old crew back again - but he was not going to lose any sleep over it. In speaking of the trouble in Whitaker's - he said he did not take any stock in the reports of the [jussis] as the were generally exaggerated he said he had heard of trouble in and about Brookville but he passed through there at all hours in the night but had not seen any violence.

  I took dinner at Whittaker's Restaurant - and drew one of the waiters into conversation but he seemed to know nothing about the Sunday night affair -
  As No 1046 Union Ave. appears to be a rendavouz of the Strikers I spent some time in there I [fancied] a party of about a dozen of the strikers while talking of the strike they they seemed to be in good humor and made joking remarks about their positions being lost and their manner clearly indicated their cause lost.   My Operative W.H.C further reports as follows:
  Friday April 6th/88
  "I left the Agency at 7 a.m. and proceeded to the vicinity of Union Depot and associated with the strikers who are assembled at 1046 Union Ave. I listened to their conversation, but as they only occasionally talked on the question of the present trouble did not learn anything new. I do not hear any of their using any threats whatsoever. They seem to accept the situation and from their manner one would suppose that they felt satisfied that the strike has failed and make known their intention of seeking work elsewhere. Some intend going down into Mexico and
Completed

work on the Mexican Central R.R. One speaks of going to Omaha tonight and another to [Easters] Kansas. I joined three of the strikers named Mulligan, Boulton and Roberts and they were talking about the strike. They seemed to think that it could be settled very I soon. I spoke to one of them about the fuss in Whittaker's restaurant but they did not appear to know anything about it. During the mourning I saw Murray of he New Albany Hotel. I took dinner at Whittaker's restaurant and sat at one of the other tables today and spoke of the fuss to the waiter a different one from yesterday, but he said that he did not know any of the parties and was not there at the time of the fuss. I also spoke to the "barker" of the restaurant who is called "Jive" and he also said that he did not know any of the parties and was not there at the time, as it occurred early in the morning. I remained in the vicinity until 6:10 p.m., where I discontinued and returned to the
Completed

Agency".

  My Operative W.J.C. further reports as follows:
  Friday April 6th/88.
  "I left my residence at 8 o'clock a.m. and proceeded to the Union Depot. Everything was quiet there and from there I went to 1046 Union Ave., the loafing place of the striking engineers; waiting around there until about 10 o'clock before the railroad men began to gather. I became pretty well acquainted with one of the striking engineers. Con. Callahan by name, who, after taking a drink and a cigar told me in the course of the conversation that they hardly hoped to be successful, but the next time they resort to some other method. Some of the boys had gone to work now, but for his part if the matter was settled satisfactorily to-day, he would not like to go work for a month, as you can't tell what the boys friends may do in the way of putting obstructions on the track. Some of his friends came up just then and I did not
Completed

have an opportunity to talk any more with him. Then I went to see the barber again at 1066 Union Ave, Scabs by name. He said he was well acquainted with David Stephens, the man who did the slugging at Whittaker's restaurant on Sunday night and gave a pretty good discription. At least it coresponds with the description that I got from the night watchman who met him as he was coming out of Whittaker's just after the row. Which occurred about 2 o'clock a.m. The Watchman's name is W.N. Corstawy with Capt. McGraw Stephens is a man about 35 years of age; weight about 170 pounds; 5 feet 10 or 11 inches in height; dark complexion, Dark, sandy moustache; is married; has a boy 5 or 4 years old; lives at 628 Locust st. I left the depot at 5:50 p.m., went to supper and reported at the Agency at 8 o'clock."

Kansas City, April 13/88.
  C.B. & Q R.R.
  Sir: 
  In continuation of the above operation
  My Operative C.F.C reports as follows:
  Thursday, April 12/88.
  "I left the Agency at 12:30 p.m. and proceeded to the Union Depot for the purpose of gathering such facts as were of interest to the company. Upon my arrival at the depot I moved around the railroad yards. I entered into conversation with one of the striking engineers, who stated that he was rather sick of the strike and would be pleased for an opportunity to resume work. He was also complaining about the Brotherhood paying some members more than others I noticed that the switchmen were all at work and neither saw not heard anything that would indicate
Completed

that they intended to strike. They appeared to be doing their work cheerfully and without any indication of bad feeling towards anyone. Everything seemed quiet around the depot. I remained in that vicinity until 6 p.m. and then returned to the Agency."

  My Operative C.F.C. further reports as follows: 
  Friday, April 13/88
  "I left the Agency at 8:30 a.m. and proceeded to the Union Depot for the purpose of gathering such facts as would be of interest to the company Upon my arrival at the depot I walked through the yard and interviewed several switchmen regarding the strike. One stated that it was quiet at present but no one knew when there would be trouble and when asked if he anticipated any strike among the switchmen, stated that he did not at present and that he hoped that there would be none. Another thought it useless for labor to combat against capital and [adoauced] the idea that the roads had combined to help pay the losses sustained by the
Completed

"2" road on account of the strike and that they intended to make this a test case and also to win it. And thus diminish the liability of strikes on all roads in the future. All of the switchmen seemed to entertain a very bitter feeling toward the new engineers and vented their spite in making evil wishes and calling them "scabs" and other hard names. but I heard no threats against [bious] or property. One switchman claimed that the occupation always dangerous, was rendered more so from the fact that the new engineers were not competent men and did not understand their business thoroughly and declared that unless a certain one was changed soon, he would quit work. Everything was quiet and orderly around the yards. I remained in that vicinity till 6 p.m. and then returned to the Agency."
